Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
     * Returned to [**Location **] w/high fever and white count, less responsive on
       [**12-1**]. Re-intubated, fever to 104 in ED, copious purulent
       secretions on intubation and RLL consolidation on CT.  On levophed
       from ed b/c BP dropped around intubation. Patient dry by exam and
       labs upon arrival.
     * UCx, Sputum Cx, Blood Cx sent.
     * CT chest/abd/pelvis: IMPRESSION: 1. Compared to prior exam from
       [**2168-11-15**] there is worsening consolidation of the right
       lower lobe. Streaky opacity within the left lung base is unchanged.
       2. Extensive pleural thickening with calcified pleural plaques most
       compatible with prior asbestos exposure. 3. Small fat containing
       umbilical hernia. 4. Side port of NG tube is at the GE junction.
       Recommend advancing for optimal placement.
     * Head CT w/no ICH
     * A-line in
     * Picc line pulled, R IJ started
     * Levophed on overnight
     * INR 1.9 -> gave Vitamin K b/c of some blood in NG tube
     * DIC labs sent
     * Lactate 1 -> 2.5 -> 0.8
     * Hypernatremic so started free water boluses

   UA: RBC, moderate bacteria
   Sputum Gram Stain: 3+ GNR
   Chest CT w/ RLL consolidation, Head CT negative for ICH
   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with PMH notable for type 2 DM, HTN, recent
   subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and
   recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia
   presenting to the ED with respiratory distress and altered mental
   status.
   .
   #1 Shock, likely septic in origin: Patient's blood pressures on a line
   are higher than cuff and we are actively weaning his levophed.
   Currently on 0.03 Given that BPs declined after meds for intubation,
   patient likely volume deplete.  Patient received approximately 5L NS
   between ED and MICU stay. Has central venous access and arterial line
   for close monitoring. Received vanc/zosyn in ED -> switched to
   meropenem in MICU per ID request.  CT w/consolidation RLL and copious
   sputum upon suctioning in ED and in MICU.  Unresolved pna from prior
   admission (acinetobacter= pna source v colonization) vs new pna
   (possibly aspiration due to change in mental status?)
   - transduce a line continuously
   - maintain CVP > or = 10 with NS boluses
   - pressors to maintain MAP > 60 (currently on levophed, weaning down)
   - follow blood, urine, and sputum Cx
   - continue vanc & meropenem as discussed with ID team
   - serial EKGs and enzymes though suspect that elevated troponin and EKG
   changes related to shock/low BP/demand ischemia
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Likely related to underlying infection/shock;
   of note he has had multiple prior similar episodes with recent
   infections (bacteremia, pneumonia). Was also notably hypernatremic,
   likely due to combination of Lasix and poor PO intake after
   extubatoin.  Head CT shows no acute changes and exam at this point is
   nonfocal.  To keep in mind that patient had new embolic CVA on MRI
   during last admission, although neuro commented at that time that the
   area affected should not significantly affect his mental status.
   - monitor mental status
   - consider repeat MRI if focal neurologic deficits develop
   .
   #3 Respiratory failure: Intubated on arrival; had desat to 80s at rehab
   facility with ABG documenting pO2 in the 40s. Could be secondary to new
   pneumonia/infectious process or worsening of prior pneumonia which
   seems unlikely given broad coverage and protracted course with acute
   decompensation. Likely an aspiration event or inability to handle
   secretions with mucous plugging as mental status waned.  Demonstrated
   insufficient cough effort after extubation during prior admission.
   - wean ventilator as tolerates by ABGs
   - treat for possible pulmonary source as above
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Recent creatinine levels here
   1.6-2 with current level now 2.4. Continue to monitor. Suspect that
   slight elevation currently due to hypovolemia/shock.
   - PM electrolytes today after fluid resuscitation.
   - monitor creatinine daily
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Likely related to hypovolemia due to poor PO intake at
   rehab.
   - volume repletion, including free water flushes in tube feeds
   - once euvolemic, re-evaluate for ? D5w needs versus NG flushes
   .
   # INR elevation: Likely nutritional given protracted ICU stay. One dose
   of vitamin K given for repletion.
   - DIC labs pending
   - Consider additional doses of Vitamin K
   .
   # UGI bleed: small amount of coffee ground like secretions from NG
   tube. INR elevated, in setting of likely septic shock, concern for DIC.
   - DIC labs as above
   - vitamin K given
   - follow coags
   - PPI to [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   # Type 2 DM:
   - fingersticks four times daily
   - sliding scale insulin
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis:
   - continue vancomycin (Planned course until [**12-21**])
   - follow blood cultures
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds as per nutrition recs from prior admission.
   Repleting electrolytes as needed.
   .
   # PPx: PPI [**Hospital1 **], bowel regimen, heparin SC TID
   .
   # ACCESS: R IJ CVL, right A line, PIV
   .
   # CODE: Full code, confirmed with wife. Consent for ICU in chart.
   .
   # COMM: With patient and family. Wife [**Name (NI) 625**] is HCP. Phone #
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2577**].
   .
   # DISP: ICU care for now.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and altered mental status. He presented to the emergency department with respiratory distress and altered mental status. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU due to the following potential medical complications:

1. Shock, likely septic in origin: The patient's blood pressures are fluctuating, indicating a possible volume depletion. He has received approximately 5 liters of normal saline between the ED and MICU stay. The patient has central venous access and an arterial line for close monitoring. He is currently on levophed, weaning down, and will be maintained with NS boluses, pressors to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) >60, continuous blood, urine, and sputum cultures, as well as ongoing administration of vancomycin and meropenem as discussed with the ID team.

2. Altered mental status: This is likely related to underlying infection/shock. The patient has had multiple prior similar episodes with recent infections (bacteremia, pneumonia). He was also notably hypernatremic, likely due to the combination of Lasix and poor PO intake after extubation. A head CT shows no acute changes, and the exam at this point is nonfocal. It is important to consider that the patient had a new embolic CVA on

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male who presented to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory failure, shock, and fever. The patient's condition has been complicated by several factors, including sepsis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and multiorgan dysfunction. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation, multi-lumen catheter, arterial line, and receiving multiple medications including norepinephrine, midazolam, heparin sodium, pantoprazole, and others.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the prolonged use of mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Prolonged immobility and central venous catheters increase the risk of blood clots in the deep veins.
3. Stress ulcers: The patient's critical condition and use of corticosteroids may increase the risk of stress ulcers in the stomach or duodenum.
4. Nosocomial infections: The patient's compromised immune system due to sepsis and prolonged hospital stay increases the risk of acquiring infections from healthcare-associated sources.
5. ARDS progression: The patient's lungs may continue to deteriorate, leading to worsening respiratory function and potential need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
6. Organ dysfunction: Multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS) can occur as a result of severe sepsis and inadequate

   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia now with respiratory failure and
   fever.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Intubated on vent. Satting well now w/ PO2 147.
   PO2/FiO2 >300 so likely not ARDS. Likely PNA w/ GNR growing from
   sputum. Also contribution from aspiration likely as he does not clear
   secretions appropriately.
   - wean FiO2 to 30%
   - Vanco/Meropenem empirically for now
   - F/U sputum cultures
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent now but responding
   appropriately to commands. Likely [**2-6**] sepsis as he has presented this
   way before.
   - Follow mental status as he is weaned from sedation after weaning from
   vent.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine
   likely ATN.
   -          monitor creatinine daily
   -          Treat sepsis
   -          Support BP w/ fluid boluses as needed.
   .
   #Shock: Resolved, multifactorial sepsis and dehydration from poor PO
   intake. Cr still elevated likely ATN
   - Monitor BP w/ A line.
   .
   # INR elevation: Likely nutritional given protracted ICU stay. One dose
   of vitamin K given for repletion.
   - DIC labs pending
   - Consider additional doses of Vitamin K
   .
   # UGI bleed: small amount of coffee ground like secretions from NG
   tube. INR elevated, in setting of likely septic shock, concern for DIC.
   - DIC labs as above
   - vitamin K given
   - follow coags
   - PPI to [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   # Type 2 DM:
   - fingersticks four times daily
   - sliding scale insulin
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis:
   - continue vancomycin (Planned course until [**12-21**])
   - follow blood cultures
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds as per nutrition recs from prior admission.
   Repleting electrolytes as needed.
   .
   # PPx: PPI [**Hospital1 **], bowel regimen, heparin SC TID
   .
   # ACCESS: R IJ CVL, right A line, PIV
   .
   # CODE: Full code, confirmed with wife. Consent for ICU in chart.
   .
   # COMM: With patient and family. Wife [**Name (NI) 625**] is HCP. Phone #
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2577**].
   .
   # DISP: ICU care for now.
Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 66-year-old man with several medical conditions and complications. The chief complaint is not specified, but the patient has been admitted to the ICU for altered mental status and pneumonia. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 10 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and Vt set at 500 mL.

The patient has a history of recent subdural hematoma, recent streptococcus bovis bacteremia, MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and endocarditis involving the aortic valve. He also has a known diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus, Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and chronic renal insufficiency.

The patient's current vital signs show a temperature of 38.3°C (101°F), heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 110/52 to 139/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on 40% FiO2. The patient's physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally, a 2/6 systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border, and a small, reducible umbilical hernia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with slightly elevated creatinine and blood glucose levels. Other lab values

He has been admitted multiple times, including this current readmission from rehab with sepsis and worsening respiratory failure. The patient's chief complaints are sepsis, respiratory failure, and aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia.

From the assessment and plan section, the following potential medical complications can arise:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has likely experienced an aspiration event upon transfer to rehab, leading to acute respiratory failure. There is also concern for pre-existing pneumonia with bilateral patchy infiltrates noted. The plan includes continuing with Vancomycin and considering a change to Dobirax if ID supports it. Low Vt approach will be continued, and the patient will be moved to PSV as possible. Atrovent will be used, and follow-up cultures will be given due to the bilateral patchy infiltrates.
2. Sepsis: The patient is currently receiving Vancomycin and Meropenem, which will be continued. Broadening the antibiotic coverage may be necessary if further fevers, hypotension, or increased secretions are observed. IVF and pressors were discontinued yesterday but may need to be restarted.
3. Endocarditis/Bacteremia: Vancomycin will continue with a goal of a 6-week course.
4. Parkinson's Disease: Sinemet/Re

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia now with respiratory failure and fever. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a PO2/FiO2 ratio greater than 300, indicating no acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He has an infection with GNR growing from sputum, likely pneumonia with aspiration also contributing to respiratory failure.

The patient has altered mental status, likely due to sepsis as he has presented this way before. His renal function is compromised, with muddy brown casts on urine analysis suggesting acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His INR is elevated, possibly due to poor nutrition from a protracted ICU stay. There is concern for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) given the elevated INR and evidence of gastrointestinal bleeding from the nasogastric tube.

The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and a history of MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis. He is currently receiving antibiotics, sedation, and other supportive measures. His code status is full code, and he is being provided with ICU care.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with multiple comorbidities, including recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia, and now with respiratory failure and fever. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient's fever and muddy brown casts in the urine suggest acute kidney injury (ATN). The patient is also being treated for MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia with vancomycin and meropenem empirically. The patient has a history of altered mental status, likely due to sedation from mechanical ventilation, but is responding appropriately to commands.

The patient's lab results show an elevated white blood cell count, elevated creatinine level, elevated prothrombin time (PT), and declining platelet count. The patient also has thrombocytopenia and a prolonged PT/activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) ratio. The patient's INR is elevated at 1.4, which may be due to malnutrition from the prolonged ICU stay. The patient's electrolytes are within normal limits.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 130/61 mmHg, heart rate of 86 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on FiO2 of 30%. The patient's temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F). The patient is receiving midazolam, fentanyl, and heparin sodium prophylactically.

The patient has multiple potential medical complications, including respiratory failure due to aspiration pneumonia, altered mental status, acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy. The patient's treatment plan includes aggressive chest physical therapy and pulmonary toilet, antibiotics for Klebsiella pneumonia, supportive care for acute kidney injury, close monitoring of coagulation parameters, and management of thrombocytopenia.

In summary, the patient is a 66-year-old man with multiple comorbidities and acute complications, including respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy. The patient is receiving aggressive treatment for pneumonia and supportive care for his other conditions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old male with recurrent endocarditis who has been readmitted to the ICU with fever, sepsis, and likely aspiration pneumonitis/pneumonia. The patient's medical history includes Parkinson's disease and previous episodes of respiratory failure.

The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The ventilator settings include a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, FiO2 of 30%, and PEEP of 10 cmH2O. The plateau pressure is 25 cmH2O, and compliance is 33.3 cmH2O/mL. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.47, PaCO2 of 42 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 403.

The patient also has muddy brown casts seen on urinalysis microscopy, suggesting possible acute tubular necrosis (ATN). 

The patient's electrolyte levels are as follows: sodium 136 mEq/L, potassium 4.3 mEq/L, chloride 98 mEq/L, bicarbonate 32 mg/dL, BUN 36 mg/dL, glucose 145 mg/dL, creatinine 2.4 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 36 mg/dL. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated at 21.8 K/uL, and platelet count has decreased to 50% of baseline.

The patient is being treated with vancomycin and meropenem for sepsis and pneumonia. The plan includes continuing with pulmonary toilet, moving to pressure support ventilation (PSV), and considering tracheostomy if necessary. The patient's code status is full code, and they are currently in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
2. Sepsis: The patient is still septic, and there is a risk of progression or development of new organ dysfunctions.
3. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The presence of muddy brown casts and elevated creatinine levels suggest ATN, which can lead to renal dysfunction.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count has significantly decreased, indicating thrombocytopenia, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, particularly the potassium and chloride levels, which can affect cardiac and neuromuscular function.

 Meropenem w/Klebsiella coverage

   .

   appropriately to commands. Patient was not at baseline mental status
   during any portion of his ICU stay before, although his MS improved as
   he improved clinically.
   - Follow mental status as his pna is treated and he is weaned from the
   ventilator
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine
   likely ATN.
   -          monitor creatinine daily
   -          Treat sepsis
   -          Support BP w/ fluid boluses as needed.
   .
   #Shock: Resolved, multifactorial sepsis and dehydration from poor PO
   intake.  Not on pressors any more.  Patient still febrile.  Cr still
   elevated likely ATN given muddy brown casts.
   - follow fever curve w/oral or rectal temps (not axillary)
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   - Monitor BP w/ A line.
   .
   # INR elevation: Improved
 1.4 today.  Likely nutritional given
   protracted ICU stay. One dose of vitamin K given for repletion.  FDP,
   fibrinogen normal. No bleeding noted.
   - follow coags
   .
   # thrombocytopenia: platelets slowly declining 255 -> 136 over
   48hours.  Hemodillution v HIT-ab associated.
   - d/c heparin sc
   - IJ -> picc (w/no heparin)
   - d/c heparin flushes
   - check HIT antibody
   .

   from NG tube. INR elevated, in setting of likely septic shock, concern
   for DIC.
   - PPI to PO and QD from [**Hospital1 **].
   .

   .

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia. The patient is currently intubated on a ventilator due to respiratory failure and fever. Sputum culture showed Klebsiella PNA, with carbapenem sensitivity pending. The patient also has a history of type 2 diabetes, Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and chronic renal insufficiency.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, which carries the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI).
2. Altered mental status: The patient has been sedated and intubated but is responding appropriately to commands. Monitoring mental status as his pneumonia is treated and he is weaned from the ventilator is crucial.
3. Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: The patient has muddy brown casts on spun urine, likely indicating acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Monitoring creatinine daily and treating sepsis are important.
4. Shock: The patient had resolved, multifactorial sepsis and dehydration from poor oral intake. Continued monitoring of blood pressure and fluid status is necessary.
5. INR elevation: The patient's INR has improved

   #1 Respiratory failure: Likely second to aspiration pneumonia given
   clinical presentation and sputum Cx w/Klebsiella.  Intubated on vent.
   On PSV w/good ABG. Tolerating vent weaning well.  Klebsiella sensitive
   to meropenem.
   - continue vanc/meropenem
 vanco to 750mg QD starting at 8pm tonight.
   - re-check vanco trough after 3 doses (7pm on [**12-8**])
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent now but responding
   appropriately to commands. Patient was not at baseline mental status
   during any portion of his ICU stay before, although his MS improved as
   he improved clinically.
   - Follow mental status as his pna is treated and he is weaned from the
   ventilator
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine
   likely ATN. Cr improving. Vanco dosing changed based on renal failure,
   high troughs.
   -          monitor creatinine daily
   -          Treat sepsis
   -          Support BP w/ fluid boluses as needed.
   .
   #Shock: Resolved, multifactorial sepsis and dehydration from poor PO
   intake.  Not on pressors any more.  Patient still febrile.  Cr still
   elevated likely ATN given muddy brown casts.
   - follow fever curve w/oral or rectal temps (not axillary)
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   - Monitor BP w/ A line.
   .
   # thrombocytopenia: platelets slowly declined 255 -> 136 over 48hours,
   now stable.  Hemodillution v HIT-ab associated.
   Heparin sc d/c. Saline flushes only.
   - HIT antibody pending
   .
   # INR elevation: Improved
 1.3 today.  Likely nutritional given
   protracted ICU stay. One dose of vitamin K given initially for
   repletion in setting of ?UGI bleed.  FDP, fibrinogen normal. No
   bleeding noted.
   - follow coags
   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  Small amount of coffee ground like secretions
   from NG tube. INR elevated, in setting of likely septic shock, concern
   for DIC.
   - PPI to PO and QD from [**Hospital1 **].
   .
   # Type 2 DM:
   - fingersticks four times daily
   - sliding scale insulin
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis:
   - continue vancomycin (Planned course until [**12-21**])
   - follow blood cultures
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Tremor worse since this admission.  Continue

   at home and was started on lower dose in MICU (oversight)
 to increase

   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .

   .

   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of recent subdural hematoma, strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and altered mental status. He was admitted to the MICU for pneumonia and is now experiencing respiratory failure. The patient has been intubated and placed on pressure support ventilation (PSV) with good arterial blood gas (ABG) results. His sputum culture revealed Klebsiella pneumonia, which is sensitive to meropenem. The patient is currently receiving meropenem and vancomycin therapy.

The patient's mental status has improved as his clinical condition improves. His acute on chronic renal insufficiency is being monitored, and muddy brown casts indicate acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His creatinine levels are improving, and vancomycin dosing has been adjusted based on renal failure.

The patient had resolved shock due to multifactorial sepsis and dehydration. He is no longer on pressors but remains febrile. His platelet count has declined from 255 to 136 over 48 hours but is currently stable. Heparin subcutaneous administration has been discontinued.

The patient's elevated INR is likely due to malnutrition from his prolonged ICU stay. One dose of vitamin K was given initially, and coagulation will continue to be monitored.

The patient had a resolved upper gastrointestinal (UGI) bleed with coffee ground-like secretions from the

The patient is receiving multiple medications including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain management.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of strep bovis endocarditis, enterococcal bacteremia, and Acinetobacter pneumonia who was readmitted from rehab with aspiration pneumonia and sepsis. He is currently in the ICU and is critically ill.

The patient's chief complaint is respiratory failure and sepsis. He has been febrile with sputum showing ESBL Klebsiella that is sensitive to meropenem. He has a known allergy to penicillins, which may limit the antibiotic options available.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.7°C (101.6°F), heart rate of 94 bpm, blood pressure of 148/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on supplemental oxygen.

The patient is on several medications, including midazolam (Versed) infusion, fentanyl, levoxyl, lipitor, ASA, sinemet, ropinirole, MVI, calcitriol, and prevacide.

The patient's flow sheet data shows that he has received a significant amount of fluids and blood products over the past 24 hours. His respiratory support includes being on CPAP/PSV mode with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O, and an FiO2 of 30%.

   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia now with respiratory failure and
   fever.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Sputum culture growing Klebsiella, sensitive to
   meropenem.  Currently on CPAP/PS tolerating well on 10 PEEP.  Will
   continue to treat PNA, and aggressive chest PT given thick secretions.
   - continue vanc/meropenem
 vanco to 750mg IV q24
   - re-check vanco trough tomorrow night
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   Will vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated.
   - Follow mental status as his pna is treated and he is weaned from the
   ventilator
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine
   likely ATN. Cr improving. Vanco dosing changed based on renal failure,
   high troughs.
   -          monitor creatinine
   -          Renally dose medications
   .
   #Shock: Still has some low grade temperatures but is otherwise
   hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating Klebsiella PNA. Yeast on
   urine culture yesterday, foley was replaced.
   - follow fever curve
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   - RIJ, Aline in place
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Today platelets slowly recovering. Will send
   off serotonin release assay for confirmation.
   -serotonin release assay f/u
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.4, slightly increased from yesterday.  Likely
   nutritional in nature. Not actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin
   K and follow coags.
   - follow coags
   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  No bloody output from NG today. Monitoring
   coags. On PPI.
   - PPI qd
   .
   # Type 2 DM: slightly elevated FS over last night, will place on
   standing NPH along with SSI.
   - NPH 3U am and pm
   - fingersticks four times daily
   - sliding scale insulin
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vancomycin (Planned course until [**12-21**])
   - follow blood cultures
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .

   Repleting electrolytes as needed. Multivitamin
   .

   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia. He is now experiencing respiratory failure and fever. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation with pressure support ventilation (PSV) and good arterial blood gas (ABG) results. He is tolerating weaning from the ventilator well.

The patient's mental status has been altered during his ICU stay, but he is responding appropriately to commands. His mental status is expected to improve as his pneumonia is treated and he is weaned from the ventilator.

The patient has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, as indicated by muddy brown casts on spun urine, likely acute tubular necrosis (ATN). His creatinine levels are improving, and vancomycin dosing has been adjusted based on renal failure and high troughs. Daily monitoring of creatinine is recommended, along with treating sepsis, supporting blood pressure with fluid boluses as needed, and following the fever curve with oral or rectal temperatures.

The patient had shock, which has resolved due to multifactorial sepsis and dehydration from poor oral intake. He is no longer on pressors but remains febrile. His creatinine is still elevated, likely due to ATN given the presence of muddy brown casts. IV fluids as needed, antibiotics

The patient is on mechanical ventilation with an endotracheal tube and receives continuous midazolam and intermittent fentanyl infusions for sedation and pain management.

Other lab results reveal elevated D-dimer levels, normal fibrinogen levels, and normal lactic acid levels.

   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia now with respiratory failure and
   fever.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Sputum culture growing Klebsiella, sensitive to
   meropenem.  Currently on CPAP/PS tolerating well on 10 PEEP.  Will
   continue to treat PNA, and aggressive chest PT given thick secretions.
   - continue vanc/meropenem
 vanco to 750mg IV q24
   - re-check vanco trough tomorrow night
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   Will vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated.
   - Follow mental status as his pna is treated and he is weaned from the
   ventilator
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine
   likely ATN. Cr improving. Vanco dosing changed based on renal failure,
   high troughs.
   -          monitor creatinine
   -          Renally dose medications
   .
   #Shock: Still has some low grade temperatures but is otherwise
   hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating Klebsiella PNA. Yeast on
   urine culture yesterday, foley was replaced.
   - follow fever curve
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   - RIJ, Aline in place
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Today platelets slowly recovering. Will send
   off serotonin release assay for confirmation.
   -serotonin release assay f/u
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.4, slightly increased from yesterday.  Likely
   nutritional in nature. Not actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin
   K and follow coags.
   - follow coags
   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  No bloody output from NG today. Monitoring
   coags. On PPI.
   - PPI qd
   .
   # Type 2 DM: slightly elevated FS over last night, will place on
   standing NPH along with SSI.
   - NPH 3U am and pm
   - fingersticks four times daily
   - sliding scale insulin
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vancomycin (Planned course until [**12-21**])
   - follow blood cultures
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds as per nutrition recs from prior admission.
   Repleting electrolytes as needed. Multivitamin
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen
   .
   # ACCESS: R IJ CVL, right A line, PIV
   .
   # CODE: Full code, confirmed with wife. Consent for ICU in chart.
   .
   # COMM: With patient and family. Wife [**Name (NI) 625**] is HCP. Phone #
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2577**].
   .
   # DISP: ICU care for now.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia now with respiratory failure and fever. The patient has multiple medical conditions including respiratory failure, altered mental status, acute on chronic renal insufficiency, shock, thrombocytopenia, INR elevation, UGI bleed, type 2 diabetes mellitus, MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis, Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and recent Foley catheter insertion. The patient is currently on CPAP/PSV ventilation, sedated, and intubated.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure due to pneumonia. The sputum culture has grown Klebsiella, which is sensitive to meropenem. The patient is currently on CPAP/PSV and will continue to treat pneumonia and perform aggressive chest physiotherapy. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored.

2. Altered Mental Status: The patient has altered mental status, which has improved slightly but is difficult to assess while on sedation. The patient will be weaned off sedation and ventilation as tolerated. The mental status should be followed as the pneumonia is treated and the patient is weaned from the ventilator.

3. Acute on Chronic Renal Ins

   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia now with respiratory failure and
   fever.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Sputum culture growing Klebsiella, sensitive to
   meropenem.  Tolerating CPAP/PS well on 5 PEEP for long periods.  Will
   continue to treat PNA, and aggressive chest PT given thick secretions.
   - continue meropenem  for 14 day course through [**12-14**], vanco 750mg IV
   q24 through [**12-16**]
   - re-check vanco trough tonight prior to 4^th 750mg dose
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   -Given multiple failed extubations in past likely will need tach for
   extended weaning and suction ability. Mentioned to family [**12-6**] will
   discuss further today. If family agrees call IP.
   -Appears volume overloaded, give 40mg IV lasix today. With goal of 1L
   negative
   -check pm lytes
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   Will vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated.
   - Follow mental status as his pna is treated and he is weaned from the
   ventilator
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine
   likely ATN. Cr improving. Vanco dosing changed based on renal failure,
   high troughs.
   - monitor creatinine, UOP
   - Renally dose medications
   - diuresis as above.
   .
   # Cards: Decreased ectopy after started metoprolol
   - Increased metoprolol to 25 TID
   .
   #Shock: Still has some low grade temperatures but is otherwise
   hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating Klebsiella PNA. Yeast on
   urine culture [**12-4**], foley was replaced.
   - follow fever curve, steadly decreasing
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   - RIJ, Aline in place
   - Awaiting PICC placement but will not give until afebrile
   .
   #Metabolic alkalosis: Likely [**2-6**] diuresis and insensible losses,
   continue to monitor.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Today platelets slowly recovering. -Pending
   serotonin release assay for confirmation.
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.4 stable.  Likely nutritional in nature. Not
   actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin K and follow coags.
   - follow coags
   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  No bloody output from NG today. Monitoring
   coags. On PPI.
   - PPI qd
   .
   # Type 2 DM: FS still elevated dispite NPH and ISS
   - changed to 15 glargine and ISS increased
   - fingersticks four times daily
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vancomycin (Planned course until [**12-16**])
   - follow blood cultures
   - trough goal 15-20 per ID
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds as per nutrition recs from prior admission.
   Repleting electrolytes as needed. Multivitamin
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, pneumoboots
   .

   - PICC when afebrile

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old man admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, pneumonia, and respiratory failure. He has a history of recent subdural hematoma, strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and chronic renal insufficiency. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, and has been diagnosed with Klebsiella pneumonia. He is tolerating CPAP/PSV well on 5 cmH2O PEEP and will continue to treat pneumonia with meropenem. The patient appears to be volume overloaded, so Lasix will be given to remove excess fluid. Mental status improvement is expected as he is weaned from the ventilator. Renal function is being closely monitored, and medications are being dosed accordingly. The patient has shown signs of shock, but is now hemodynamically stable. A Foley catheter has been replaced, and a PICC line will be placed once the patient is afebrile. The patient has tested positive for HIT antibodies, which have been confirmed through a serotonin release assay. Other medical conditions include type 2 diabetes, MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis, Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and acute kidney injury.

3. Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine likely indicate acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Creatinine levels are improving. Vancomycin dosing has been changed based on renal failure, high troughs. The patient's creatinine levels should be monitored, and medications should be dosed accordingly.
4. Shock: The patient still has some low-grade

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia. He is currently in respiratory failure and has a fever. The patient has been treated with meropenem for pneumonia, vancomycin for MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis, and lasix for volume overload. He is sedated and intubated, but his mental status has improved slightly. The patient also has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, muddy brown casts on urine indicating ATN, and an elevated creatinine level. His cardiac condition is improving after starting metoprolol. The patient is still at risk for shock, metabolic alkalosis, thrombocytopenia (HIT), elevated INR, UGI bleed, Type 2 DM, Parkinson's disease, and hypothyroidism. He is starting tube feeds and receiving multivitamins. The patient has multiple lines including R IJ CVL, right A line, PIV, and will have a PICC placement when afebrile. His code status is full code, and he is currently in ICU care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently experiencing respiratory failure due to pneumonia. He is on mechanical ventilation and receiving aggressive chest physiotherapy and suctioning.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 72-year-old male with a chief complaint of hypotension. The patient has a history of Parkinson's disease, respiratory failure, electrolyte and fluid disorder, altered mental status, and fever of unknown origin. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for further management. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure indicates a potential risk for inadequate organ perfusion and possible organ damage. It is crucial to address this issue promptly and monitor the patient closely.
2. Electrolyte and Fluid Disorder: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels (e.g., low sodium, potassium, and magnesium) and fluid balance suggest a potential risk for cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other systemic complications. Close monitoring and correction of these imbalances are necessary.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be attributed to various factors, including medication side effects, infection, or inadequate oxygenation. Continuous neurologic monitoring and assessment are needed to ensure the patient's well-being.
4. Fever of Unknown Origin: The patient's persistent fever indicates an underlying infection or inflammatory process. Further investigations are required to identify the source of infection and initiate appropriate treatment.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure, although previously noted, should still be closely monitored for any deterioration in oxygenation or ventilation parameters. Adequate oxygen delivery and weaning from mechanical ventilation should be considered when clinically appropriate

   PNA, and aggressive chest PT given thick secretions.  Given multiple
   failed extubations in past complicated w/aspiration and inability to
   clear secretions with cough likely will need tacheostomy for extended
   weaning and suction ability. Mentioned to family [**12-6**] will discuss
   further today. If family agrees will call thoracic surgery to place
   tracheostomy and likely peg at same time. Vanco trough 18.4.
   - continue meropenem  for 14 day course through [**12-14**], vanco 750mg IV
   q24 through [**12-16**]
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet

   .

   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   With vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated
   and follow mental status.
   .

   likely ATN. Cr improving. Vanco dosing changed based on renal failure,
   high troughs.
   - monitor creatinine, UOP
   - renally dose medications
   - diuresis held because
   .

s systolic after third dose of Metoprolol

   -          decrease Metoprolol to 12.5 TID
   -          hold diuresis
   -          IVF prn
   .

   severely after Metoprolol increased to TID, so will
   - Increased metoprolol to 25 TID
   .
   #Shock: Fever has resolved. One episode of hypotension but unlikely due
   to sepsis. Now hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating Klebsiella
   PNA. Yeast on urine culture [**12-4**], foley was replaced.
   - follow fever curve
   - IVF as needed

   .
   #Metabolic alkalosis: Likely [**2-6**] diuresis, insensible loss, and likely

   .

   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with recent subdural hematoma, streptococcus bovis bacteremia, MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and pneumonia. He is currently in the ICU for altered mental status and respiratory failure. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV and has tolerated it well with 5 cmH2O PEEP. His fever has resolved, and secretions have decreased. There is a sputum culture growing Klebsiella, which is sensitive to meropenem. The patient will continue to be treated for pneumonia and may require a tracheostomy for extended weaning and suction ability.

The patient's altered mental status has slightly improved but is difficult to assess while on sedation. Sedation will be gradually reduced as tolerated and mental status will be monitored. The patient also has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, with muddy brown casts on spun urine likely indicating acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Creatinine levels are improving, and vancomycin dosing has been adjusted based on renal failure.

The patient experienced hypotension after the third dose of metoprolol and had been diuresed the previous day. Hypotension improved with 1.25 L normal saline. Metoprolol has been decreased to 12.5 TID, diuresis has been held, and IV fluids will be given as needed.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with aspiration pneumonia who is currently in the ICU. The patient has experienced several medical complications during his stay. 

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has respiratory failure due to aspiration pneumonia caused by ESBL Klebsiella. He has defervesced, indicating a decrease in fever, but still requires mechanical ventilation. Tracheostomy is recommended to facilitate rehabilitation and prevent recurrent aspiration pneumonia.

2. MRSA/Enterococcus Endocarditis: The patient is being treated with vancomycin until December 16th. This suggests that he has an infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and/or enterococcus bacteria.

3. Fluid Overload: The patient has fluid overload, as indicated by his fluid balance data showing an intake of 4,399 mL and output of only 3,655 mL over 24 hours. Diuretics may be considered to manage this condition, but the patient's blood pressure needs to remain stable.

4. Ectopy: The patient has experienced ectopy, which is an irregular heart rhythm. Lopressor, a medication used to control heart rate, is being continued at a lower dose.

5. Other findings: The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and glucose levels. His potassium and sodium levels are within normal range. The patient also has elevated liver enzymes (AST

   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia now with respiratory failure and
   fever.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Sputum culture growing Klebsiella, sensitive to
   meropenem.  Tolerating CPAP/PS well on 5 PEEP for long periods.  Fever
   is resolved now and secretions have decreased.  Will continue to treat
   PNA, and aggressive chest PT given thick secretions.  Given multiple
   failed extubations in past complicated w/aspiration and inability to
   clear secretions with cough likely will need tacheostomy for extended
   weaning and suction ability. Mentioned to family [**12-6**] will discuss
   further today. If family agrees will call thoracic surgery to place
   tracheostomy and likely peg at same time. Vanco trough 18.4.
   - continue meropenem  for 14 day course through [**12-14**], vanco 750mg IV
   q24 through [**12-16**]
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   With vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated
   and follow mental status.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Muddy brown casts on spun urine
   likely ATN. Cr improving. Vanco dosing changed based on renal failure,
   high troughs.
   - monitor creatinine, UOP
   - renally dose medications
   - diuresis held because
   .
   #Hypotension: BP down to 70
s systolic after third dose of Metoprolol
   25mg given. Patient had also been diuresed yesterday which likely
   contributed to hypotension. Improved with 1.25 L NS. Was afebrile.
   -          decrease Metoprolol to 12.5 TID
   -          hold diuresis
   -          IVF prn
   .
   # Ectopy: Decreased ectopy after started metoprolol but BP dropped
   severely after Metoprolol increased to TID, so will
   - Increased metoprolol to 25 TID
   .
   #Shock: Fever has resolved. One episode of hypotension but unlikely due
   to sepsis. Now hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating Klebsiella
   PNA. Yeast on urine culture [**12-4**], foley was replaced.
   - follow fever curve
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   - RIJ, Aline in place
   - PICC placement today?
   .
   #Metabolic alkalosis: Likely [**2-6**] diuresis, insensible loss, and likely
   a relative metabolic alkalosis because of compensation for chronic CO2
   retention and over-ventillation on vent. Improved on repeat ABG.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Today platelets slowly recovering. -Pending
   serotonin release assay for confirmation.
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.4 stable.  Likely nutritional in nature. Not
   actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin K and follow coags.
   - follow coags
   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  No bloody output from NG today. Monitoring
   coags. On PPI.
   - PPI qd
   .
   # Type 2 DM: FS still elevated dispite NPH and ISS
   - changed to 15 glargine and ISS increased
   - fingersticks four times daily
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vancomycin (Planned course until [**12-16**])
   - follow blood cultures
   - trough goal 15-20 per ID
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds as per nutrition recs from prior admission.
   Repleting electrolytes as needed. Multivitamin
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, pneumoboots, start fondoperinox.
   .
   # ACCESS: R IJ CVL, right A line, PIV
   - PICC today?
   .
   # CODE: Full code, confirmed with wife. Consent for ICU in chart.
   .
   # COMM: With patient and family. Wife [**Name (NI) 625**] is HCP. Phone #

   .

3. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest a possible infection. This increases the risk of seps

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with persistent ventilatory failure, likely aspiration-related pneumonia, and plans for a tracheostomy. He has had reasonable stability of hemodynamics but remains with continued poor mental status, persistent secretions, and concern for recurrent respiratory failure. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1) Respiratory Failure due to Klebsiella Pneumonia:
   - The patient has persistent ventilatory failure, which can lead to further respiratory distress.
   - The planned tracheostomy may help improve ventilation and reduce secretions.

2) Thrombocytopenia:
   - The patient has a low platelet count, which can increase the risk of bleeding.
   - A serotonin release assay is negative, suggesting that heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is unlikely.
   - It is important to discuss with the hematology team to determine the cause of the platelet drop and decide on appropriate management.

3) Sepsis/Endocarditis:
   - The patient is receiving continued treatment with vancomycin, likely due to concern for endocarditis.
   - Antibiotics should be continued until [12-16] to ensure adequate treatment.

Other active issues to be managed include Parkinson's disease, electrolyte and fluid disorder, altered mental status (not delirium), fever of unknown origin, nutrition through tube feeds, glycemic control using regular insulin sliding scale, arterial and PICC line management

   Assessment and Plan
   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure and fever,
   now s/p trach and PEG placement.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Secondary to Klebsiella PNA, sensitive to
   meropenem.  Trach placed yesterday w/o complications, today tolerating
   CPAP/PS well on 5 PEEP.  He continues to have bloody secretions in vent
   tube but they have decreased in quantity.  Will continue to treat PNA,
   and aggressive chest PT given secretions.
   - continue meropenem  for 14 day course through [**12-14**]
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   With vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated
   and follow mental status.
   -off drip and monitor the requirement for prn boluses, if less than q3
   can d/c drip
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: ATN in setting of sepsis.
   Creatinine continues to improve as well as fluid status.
   - monitor creatinine, UOP
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #Hypotension: One episode of SBP to 70
s systolic 2 days ago after
   third dose of Metoprolol, was responsive to fluid bolus. BP has been
   stable since then.
   -          Metoprolol low dose 12.5 TID
   .
   # Ectopy: Decreased ectopy after started metoprolol but BP dropped
   severely after Metoprolol increased to TID, so will keep low dose for
   now.
   .
   #Shock: Fever has resolved. One episode of hypotension but unlikely due
   to sepsis (as above). Now hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating
   Klebsiella PNA.
   - follow fever curve
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vanco 750mg IV q24 through [**12-16**]
   - follow blood cultures
   - trough goal 15-20 per ID
   .
   #Metabolic alkalosis: Likely [**2-6**] diuresis, insensible loss, and likely
   a relative metabolic alkalosis because of compensation for chronic CO2
   retention and over-ventillation on vent. Improved on repeat ABG.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Today platelets slowly recovering. Serotonin
   release assay negative but was done 2 days after heparin d/c. Will call
   hematology today to discuss significance/whether patient should or
   should not carry a Dx of HIT.
   -heme consult recs
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.4 stable.  Likely nutritional in nature. Not
   actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin K and follow coags.
   - follow coags
   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  No further bloody output from NG since
   admission.  Likely from oropharyngeal bleeding from difficult
   intubation.  Monitoring coags. On PPI.
   - PPI qd
   .
   # Type 2 DM: FS stabilized with 15 glargine and increased ISS
   - fingersticks four times daily
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds once ok
d by IP (post-PEG). Repleting
   electrolytes as needed. Multivitamin
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, pneumoboots.
   .

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the provided information include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has pneumonia and is currently on mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of continued respiratory failure or development of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
2. Altered mental status: The patient is sedated on vent with sedation, and it is difficult to assess his mental status. Weaning off sedation will be necessary, and there is a risk of persistent altered mental status or delirium.
3. Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: The patient has a history of renal insufficiency and is currently experiencing acute kidney injury likely due to sepsis. Close monitoring of creatinine and urine output is required, along with adjustment of medications accordingly.
4. Hypotension: The patient had an episode of hypotension with a systolic blood pressure of 70 after receiving metoprolol. This could indicate septic shock or a reaction to the medication. Ongoing monitoring and appropriate fluid management are essential.

   .

s systolic 2 days ago after third dose of
   Metoprolol 25mg given. Patient had also been diuresed which likely
   contributed to hypotension. Improved with 1.25 L NS. Was afebrile.  BP

   -          hold diuresis
   -          IVF prn
   .
   # Ectopy: Decreased ectopy after started metoprolol but BP dropped
   severely after Metoprolol increased to TID, so will keep low dose for
   now.
   .
   #Shock: Fever has resolved. One episode of hypotension but unlikely due
   to sepsis. Now hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating Klebsiella
   PNA. Yeast on urine culture [**12-4**], foley was replaced.
   - follow fever curve
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   - Aline, picc in place
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.

   - follow blood cultures

   hematology today to discuss significance/whether patient should or

   .

   actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin K and follow coags.

   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  No further bloody output from NG since

   - PPI qd

   # Type 2 DM: FS stabilized with 15 glargine and increased ISS

   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for

   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds as per nutrition recs from prior admission.

   .

The patient is a 66-year-old man with recent subdural hematoma, recent streptococcus bovis bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia. The patient now has respiratory failure and fever. The patient tolerates CPAP/PSV well on 5 PEEP for long periods. The fever has resolved now and secretions have decreased. The patient will continue to treat PNA and aggressive chest PT given thick secretions. Given multiple failed extubations in the past complicated with aspiration and inability to clear secretions with cough, the patient needs tracheostomy for extended weaning and suction ability. 

The patient's altered mental status has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation. With vent weaning, the patient will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated and follow mental status. 

The patient has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, with muddy brown casts on spun urine likely ATN. Creatinine is improving. Vancomycin dosing was changed based on renal failure, high troughs. 

The patient's blood pressure dropped severely after metoprolol was increased, so it will be kept low dose for now. 

The patient had a recent episode of hypotension but unlikely due to sepsis. Now hemodynamically stable. Actively treating Klebsiella PNA. Yeast on urine culture, foley was replaced.

The patient underwent tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. 

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure secondary to Klebsiella pneumonia, which is sensitive to meropenem. The patient tolerated CPAP/PSV well on 5 cmH2O and continues to have bloody secretions in the vent tube but in decreased quantity. 

The patient also has altered mental status, which has slightly improved but is difficult to assess while on sedation. The patient is being weaned off the ventilator, and sedation will be decreased as tolerated. 

Additionally, the patient has acute on chronic renal insufficiency due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) in the setting of sepsis. Creatinine continues to improve along with fluid status. 

The patient experienced one episode of hypotension to 70 systolic two days ago after the third dose of metoprolol, which was responsive to a fluid bolus. The patient's blood pressure has been stable since then.

   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure and fever,
   now s/p trach and PEG placement.
   .
   #1 Respiratory failure: Secondary to Klebsiella PNA, sensitive to
   meropenem.  Trach placed yesterday w/o complications, today tolerating
   CPAP/PS well on 5 PEEP.  He continues to have bloody secretions in vent
   tube but they have decreased in quantity.  Will continue to treat PNA,
   and aggressive chest PT given secretions.
   - continue meropenem  for 14 day course through [**12-14**]
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   .
   #2 Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   With vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated
   and follow mental status.
   -off drip and monitor the requirement for prn boluses, if less than q3
   can d/c drip
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: ATN in setting of sepsis.
   Creatinine continues to improve as well as fluid status.
   - monitor creatinine, UOP
   - renally dose medications
   .
   #Hypotension: One episode of SBP to 70
s systolic 2 days ago after
   third dose of Metoprolol, was responsive to fluid bolus. BP has been
   stable since then.
   -          Metoprolol low dose 12.5 TID
   .
   # Ectopy: Decreased ectopy after started metoprolol but BP dropped
   severely after Metoprolol increased to TID, so will keep low dose for
   now.
   .
   #Shock: Fever has resolved. One episode of hypotension but unlikely due
   to sepsis (as above). Now hemodynamically stable.  Actively treating
   Klebsiella PNA.
   - follow fever curve
   - IVF as needed
   - ABx as above
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vanco 750mg IV q24 through [**12-16**]
   - follow blood cultures
   - trough goal 15-20 per ID
   .
   #Metabolic alkalosis: Likely [**2-6**] diuresis, insensible loss, and likely
   a relative metabolic alkalosis because of compensation for chronic CO2
   retention and over-ventillation on vent. Improved on repeat ABG.
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Today platelets slowly recovering. Serotonin
   release assay negative but was done 2 days after heparin d/c. Will call
   hematology today to discuss significance/whether patient should or
   should not carry a Dx of HIT.
   -heme consult recs
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.4 stable.  Likely nutritional in nature. Not
   actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin K and follow coags.
   - follow coags
   .
   # UGI bleed: Resolved.  No further bloody output from NG since
   admission.  Likely from oropharyngeal bleeding from difficult
   intubation.  Monitoring coags. On PPI.
   - PPI qd
   .
   # Type 2 DM: FS stabilized with 15 glargine and increased ISS
   - fingersticks four times daily
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Starting tube feeds once ok
d by IP (post-PEG). Repleting
   electrolytes as needed. Multivitamin
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, pneumoboots.
   .
   # ACCESS: PICC. right A line, PIV
   .
   # CODE: Full code, confirmed with wife. Consent for ICU in chart.
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure and fever. The patient underwent tracheostomy (trach) placement yesterday without complications and is tolerating CPAP/PSV well on 5 PEEP. He continues to have bloody secretions in the vent tube, but their quantity has decreased. The patient is being treated for pneumonia with meropenem and aggressive chest PT is being given due to secretions. 

The patient's altered mental status has improved slightly, but it is difficult to assess while on sedation. The plan is to continue weaning off sedation as tolerated and follow the mental status. 

The patient also has acute on chronic renal insufficiency, likely due to ATN in the setting of sepsis. Creatinine continues to improve as well as fluid status. Monitoring of creatinine and UOP is recommended, along with renal dosing of medications. 

There was one episode of hypotension (systolic blood pressure of 70) two days ago after the third dose of metoprolol, which was responsive to fluid bolus. The patient's blood pressure has been stable since then. The dose of metoprolol has been reduced to 12.5 TID. 

The patient experienced ectopy,

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure. He underwent tracheostomy and PEG placement. He is currently on mechanical ventilation and is being treated for pneumonia with meropenem and aggressive chest physiotherapy. He also has bacteremia/endocarditis and is being treated with vancomycin. His sputum gram stain shows G- diplococci, which may be Klebsiella or Acinetobacter. He has fever, UTI with yeast in the urine, thrombocytopenia (HIT), acute on chronic renal insufficiency (ATN), ectopy, MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis, INR elevation, type 2 DM, Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and FEN. He is on various medications and has multiple lines and tubes in place.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's current respiratory failure may worsen if he develops further infections or if his pneumonia does not respond to treatment.
2. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status may continue to be altered due to sedation from mechanical ventilation, underlying medical conditions, or sepsis.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 66-year-old man with a history of recent subdural hematoma, recent strep bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure. He has undergone tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. The patient is currently intubated on CPAP/PSV with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O, receiving oxygen supplementation, and being treated for pneumonia with meropenem. He is also on IV vancomycin for bacteremia/endocarditis. Sputum gram stain shows G- diplococci, and follow-up sputum cultures are pending for speciation/sensitivity.

The patient's mental status has improved slightly but remains difficult to assess due to sedation. Sedation will be weaned as tolerated, and mental status will be monitored. The cause of the patient's fever is unclear, and further evaluation of urine culture, blood cultures, and sputum culture results is pending. The patient has yeast in his urine, which is usually colonization but may require treatment due to the presence of WBC.

The patient has acute-on-chronic renal insufficiency, likely secondary to sepsis and ATN. Creatinine levels are improving along with fluid status. Medications will be monitored for renal dosing. The patient has thrombocytopenia, with

   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure and fever,
   now s/p trach and PEG placement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Secondary to Aspiration PNA w/Klebsiella,
   sensitive to meropenem.  Tracheostomy placed due to aspiration in
   setting of recent extubation and copious secretions w/poor cough
   strength. No complications with trachestomy, tolerating CPAP/PS well on
   PEEP of 5.  Min secretions on suctioning.  Treating pneumonia w/
   meropenem and aggressive chest PT.  Also on IV vancomycin, for
   bacteremia/endocarditis.  Sputum gram stain showing G (-) diplococci,
   cx with gram (-) rods (two strains) Considering acinetobacter based on
   previous growth from patient
s sputum.
   - follow sputum cultures for speciation/sensitivity
   - continue meropenem  for 14 day course through [**12-14**]
   - starting unasyn for presumptive acinetobacter
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   # Fever: Unclear cause. Patient with yeast in urine but unlikely cause
   for fever. Now 48h post-op so unlikely due to recent tracheostomy.
   Sputum gram stain with GNR, but unclear whether this is an infection
   vs. colonization.
   -          last UA negative for yeast, LE, nitr
   -          follow  BCx
   -          follow Sputum Cx
   -          no need to tx funguria per ID.
   .
   # Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   With vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated
   and follow mental status.
   -off drip and monitor the requirement for prn boluses, if less than q3
   can d/c drip
   .
   # UTI: No yeast in last UA. Contaminated with epi
s. Prior yeast may be
   colonization, but patient has had foley changed once already and no
   yeast in urine.
   -re-change foley.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: ATN in setting of sepsis.
   Creatinine improving with fluid status.
   - monitor creatinine, UOP
   - renally dose medications
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Platelets recovering. Serotonin release assay
   negative but was done 2 days after heparin d/c.
   - Heme
 continue Fondaparinux and use for subsequent hospitalizations,
   no direct discussion of HIT
   .
   # Ectopy: Decreased ectopy after started metoprolol but BP dropped
   severely after Metoprolol increased to TID.  Now on low dose metoprolol
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vanco 750mg IV q24 through [**12-16**]
   - follow blood cultures
   - trough goal 15-20 per ID
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.5 stable.  Likely nutritional in nature. Not
   actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin K and follow coags.
   .
   # Type 2 DM: FS stabilized with 15 glargine and increased ISS.  No
   changes.
   - fingersticks four times daily
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Tube feeds via peg. Repleting electrolytes as needed.
   Multivitamin.
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, pneumoboots.  Cont  fondoparinux
   .
   # ACCESS: PICC. PIV. Pulled A-line.
   .

   .

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with recent subdural hematoma, recent streptococcal bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia, and recent admission to the MICU for altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure. He underwent tracheostomy placement due to aspiration in the setting of recent extubation and copious secretions with poor cough strength. He is currently on IV vancomycin for bacteremia/endocarditis and meropenem for pneumonia. He also has a Foley catheter in place. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he remains sedated on the ventilator. His mental status has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has pneumonia with Klebsiella sensitivity to meropenem. He is currently being treated with meropenem and aggressive chest physiotherapy. There are no immediate complications with the tracheostomy.
2. Fever: The cause of the fever is unclear. The patient has yeast in his urine but it is unlikely to be the cause of the fever. Sputum gram stain shows gram-negative rods, but it is unclear whether this is an infection or colonization.
3. Altered mental status: The patient is sedated on the ventilator, which makes it difficult to assess his mental status accurately. As he is weaned off the sedation, his mental status should improve.

   PEEP of 5.  Min secretions on suctioning.  Treating pneumonia w/
   meropenem and aggressive chest PT.  Also on IV vancomycin, for
   bacteremia/endocarditis.  Sputum gram stain showing G (-) diplococci,
   cx with gram (-) rods (two strains) Considering acinetobacter based on

s sputum.

- The patient is being treated for pneumonia with meropenem and aggressive chest PT. Additionally, the patient is on IV vancomycin for bacteremia/endocarditis.
- The sputum gram stain shows G (-) diplococci, and the patient is being followed for speciation/sensitivity.
- The patient's fever is unclear in origin, and no clear cause has been identified. The yeast in the urine is unlikely to be the cause of the fever, and the sputum gram stain with GNR is unclear whether it is an infection or colonization.
- The patient's mental status has improved slightly but is difficult to assess while on sedation. Mental status will be monitored as the patient continues to wean off the ventilator.
- The patient has a urinary tract infection, but there is no yeast present in the last urine analysis. The Foley catheter will be re-changed.

   A/P: This is a 66 y/o man with recent subdural hematoma, recent strep
   bovis/MRSA/enterococcus bacteremia and recent admission to the MICU for
   altered mental status and pneumonia with respiratory failure and fever,
   now s/p trach and PEG placement.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Secondary to Aspiration PNA w/Klebsiella,
   sensitive to meropenem.  Tracheostomy placed due to aspiration in
   setting of recent extubation and copious secretions w/poor cough
   strength. No complications with trachestomy, tolerating CPAP/PS well on
   PEEP of 5.  Min secretions on suctioning.  Treating pneumonia w/
   meropenem and aggressive chest PT.  Also on IV vancomycin, for
   bacteremia/endocarditis.  Sputum gram stain showing G (-) diplococci,
   cx with gram (-) rods (two strains) Considering acinetobacter based on
   previous growth from patient
s sputum.
   - follow sputum cultures for speciation/sensitivity
   - continue meropenem  for 14 day course through [**12-14**]
   - starting unasyn for presumptive acinetobacter
   - aggressive chest PT and pulmonary toilet
   - atrovent/albuterol nebs prn
   # Fever: Unclear cause. Patient with yeast in urine but unlikely cause
   for fever. Now 48h post-op so unlikely due to recent tracheostomy.
   Sputum gram stain with GNR, but unclear whether this is an infection
   vs. colonization.
   -          last UA negative for yeast, LE, nitr
   -          follow  BCx
   -          follow Sputum Cx
   -          no need to tx funguria per ID.
   .
   # Altered mental status: Sedated on vent with sedation. Mental status
   has improved slightly but it is difficult to assess while on sedation.
   With vent weaning, will continue to go down on sedation as tolerated
   and follow mental status.
   -off drip and monitor the requirement for prn boluses, if less than q3
   can d/c drip
   .
   # UTI: No yeast in last UA. Contaminated with epi
s. Prior yeast may be
   colonization, but patient has had foley changed once already and no
   yeast in urine.
   -re-change foley.
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: ATN in setting of sepsis.
   Creatinine improving with fluid status.
   - monitor creatinine, UOP
   - renally dose medications
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: HIT antibody positive, off all heparin products,
   lines flushed yesterday.  Platelets recovering. Serotonin release assay
   negative but was done 2 days after heparin d/c.
   - Heme
 continue Fondaparinux and use for subsequent hospitalizations,
   no direct discussion of HIT
   .
   # Ectopy: Decreased ectopy after started metoprolol but BP dropped
   severely after Metoprolol increased to TID.  Now on low dose metoprolol
   .
   # MRSA/Enterococcus bacteremia with aortic valve endocarditis: continue
   on vancomycin and following blood cultures.
   - continue vanco 750mg IV q24 through [**12-16**]
   - follow blood cultures
   - trough goal 15-20 per ID
   .
   # INR elevation: INR 1.5 stable.  Likely nutritional in nature. Not
   actively bleeding, will hold off on vitamin K and follow coags.
   .
   # Type 2 DM: FS stabilized with 15 glargine and increased ISS.  No
   changes.
   - fingersticks four times daily
   .
   # Parkinson's disease: Continue carbidopa/levodopa and ropinirole for
   now.  Dose adjusted yesterday, will continue to monitor for tremor
   improvement.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # FEN: Tube feeds via peg. Repleting electrolytes as needed.
   Multivitamin.
   .
   # PPx: PPI, bowel regimen, pneumoboots.  Cont  fondoparinux
   .
   # ACCESS: PICC. PIV. Pulled A-line.
   .
   # CODE: Full code, confirmed with wife. Consent for ICU in chart.
   .
   # COMM: With patient and family. Wife [**Name (NI) 625**] is HCP. Phone #
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 2577**].
   .
   # DISP: call out to floor, ? rehabilitation screening
